L1_summary_of_paper: The paper examines how local agglomeration (geographic co-location) interacts with hotels’ strategic orientations (price–quality segments from economy to luxury) to shape performance in the U.S. lodging industry. It asks whether clusters with more highly differentiated (high-end) properties raise neighbors’ demand-based performance, whether clusters dense in low-cost properties depress luxury performance, and whether a hotel’s strategic distance from the local cluster norm amplifies these effects. Framing integrates agglomeration economics (local externalities) with differentiation strategy, focusing on demand-side spillovers in services. Constructs include strategic orientation (five segments), cluster composition (segment shares within census tracts), strategic distance (absolute gap between a hotel’s segment and the tract’s mean segment), and performance (RevPAR). Using a large cross-section (≈15k hotels, year 2000) and FGLS models estimated within segment with rich location and structure controls, the study finds: (1) for economy, midscale (with/without F&B), and upscale hotels, a higher local share of more-differentiated properties is associated with higher RevPAR; (2) for luxury hotels, a higher local share of lower-cost properties is associated with lower RevPAR; (3) strategic distance amplifies these effects—positive for lower-cost hotels in high-end clusters and negative for high-end hotels in low-end clusters. Contributions: recasts agglomeration in services as a redistributive demand mechanism conditional on strategy; introduces strategic distance as a moderator; bridges competitive dynamics with urban/agglomeration literatures.
M3_unit_of_analysis_element: Other: Strategic distance from local cluster norm
A1_citation: Canina, L., Enz, C. A., & Harrison, J. S. (2005). Agglomeration Effects and Strategic Orientations: Evidence from the U.S. Lodging Industry. Academy of Management Journal, 48(4), 565–581.
C3_metric_detail: Strategic orientation coded into five price–quality segments (economy, midscale–no F&B, midscale–with F&B, upscale, luxury). Cluster composition measured as segment shares within census tracts. Strategic distance = |hotel segment code (1–5) − tract mean segment|. RevPAR = annual room revenue / annual rooms available. Cluster heterogeneity via Herfindahl over segment shares; size dispersion via coefficient of variation of rooms in tract.
D2_identification: Other: FGLS with tract-level error structure
Other: Segment-specific models with rich controls
D2_key_assumptions_addressed: Within-tract correlated errors mitigated via FGLS
Observed location/structure covariates controlled (chain, size, location type, MSA demographics, region)
Segment heterogeneity handled by within-segment estimation
D5_data_sources: PKF Hospitality Research Group (RevPAR–profit correlation check)
F2_risk_of_bias_notes: Proprietary data; single-year cross-section vulnerable to omitted neighborhood attributes and selection into locations; coarse strategy categorization; potential reverse causality between cluster composition and performance not instrumented.
G1_construct_mapping_note: Map strategic orientation to price–quality tier; agglomeration composition to local competitive field; strategic distance to positional atypicality within locality.
G4_unifying_props_drafts: Demand-side agglomeration benefits increase with local differentiation and accrue disproportionately to lower-cost neighbors.
Low-cost density erodes luxury pricing power within shared clusters.
Strategic distance amplifies both positive and negative agglomeration externalities.
NA_reason_if_any: The paper’s core is an empirical estimation of agglomeration–strategy interactions rather than conceptual theorizing or synthesis.
I1_mechanism_statements: Differentiation spillover: high-end neighbors raise destination appeal, increasing local demand available to lower-cost hotels.
Dilution effect: dense low-cost presence reduces achievable prices for luxury hotels.
Distance amplification: greater deviation from local norm magnifies spillover gains for low-end and penalties for high-end.

I2_mediation_moderation_details.role_in_link: Moderates the association between cluster composition and RevPAR (effects differ across tiers).
Amplifies differentiation spillovers (positive for low-end in high-end clusters; negative for high-end in low-end clusters).
Positive for some tiers (economy, upscale, luxury) and insignificant for others (midscale).

I3_theoretical_propositions: H1a: For non-luxury segments, RevPAR increases with the local share of higher-differentiated properties.
H1b: For luxury hotels, RevPAR decreases with the local share of lower-cost properties.
H2: Strategic distance from the local average segment amplifies these effects, strengthening gains for low-end in high-end clusters and losses for high-end in low-end clusters.
J1_main_findings_summary: Positive differentiation-based agglomeration association for economy, midscale (both), and upscale hotels.
Negative association between low-cost density and luxury hotel RevPAR.
Strategic distance significantly moderates agglomeration–performance links in opposite directions by tier.
Size-based agglomeration is beneficial in some tiers and negligible in others; cluster heterogeneity effects are limited.
J2_finding_evidence_links: Hypotheses and theory sections; variable construction and data section; FGLS results tables by segment and distance interactions.
K1_contribution_summary: Provides large-scale evidence that agglomeration in services operates through demand-side spillovers that are contingent on strategic orientation and positional distance. Shows redistribution of rents across tiers: high-end investments generate externalities appropriated by lower-cost neighbors, while low-cost density penalizes luxury; introduces strategic distance as a key moderator connecting competitive dynamics and agglomeration.
